sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving coordination compounds.
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change of the reaction between hexaaquairon(III) ions and chloride ions to form tetrachloroferrate(III) ions in aqueous solution, given the following equation and standard enthalpy changes of formation?
      
      Fe(H2O)63+(aq) + 4 Cl-(aq) → FeCl4-(aq) + 6 H2O(l) 

ΔHf (Fe(H2O)63+(aq)) = -1675 kJ/mol 
ΔHf (FeCl4-(aq)) = -542 kJ/mol 
ΔHf (H2O(l)) = -285.8 kJ/mol 
ΔHf (Cl-(aq)) = -167.2 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change of the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔHreaction = Σ ΔHf(products) - Σ ΔHf(reactants)

For the products, we have:
1 mol of FeCl4-(aq) and 6 mol of H2O(l)

For the reactants, we have:
1 mol of Fe(H2O)63+(aq) and 4 mol of Cl-(aq)

Now, we can plug in the given standard enthalpy changes of formation:

ΔHreaction = [(1 × -542) + (6 × -285.8)] - [(1 × -1675) + (4 × -167.2)]

ΔHreaction = (-542 - 1714.8) - (-1675 + 668.8)

ΔHreaction = -2256.8 - (-1006.2)

ΔHreaction = -1250.6 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change of the reaction between hexaaquairon(III) ions and chloride ions to form tetrachloroferrate(III) ions in aqueous solution is -1250.6 kJ/mol.
